column2: If you like Rioja, you've almost certainly heard of CVNE (or Cune to some) before. This is their flagship red. To make it, they've shunned many of the more traditional approaches. It's made from 40-year-old vines, aged in French, American and Hungarian oak over 17 months and left in the bottle for over a year. As a result, it's complex, rich and truly indulgent. Expect notes of red and black fruit, vanilla and liquorice. Try it with Manchego. The 2017 vintage scored 94 Parker Points.
column9: Black Fruit, Liquorice, Red Fruit, Vanilla

column2: Spain’s wine laws are notoriously constrictive – so with Finca Carelio we decided to throw out the rulebook. Our buyers found the first Finca Carelio in the cellar of a top-name producer – we struck a bargain to declassify it and sell it at a low price for the quality. It was so popular that we did it again. This is a blend of wine from Castilla and Ribera del Duero – where wines are usually double the price. Rich. Ripe. Smooth. And full of jammy dark-fruit flavour. It’s deliciously easy drinking, with elegant tannins and spice. Enjoy it with roast lamb.

Matsu translates from Japanese as ‘to wait’. It perfectly captures the patient philosophy of Bodegas Matsu on their century-old Toro vineyards. The bodega’s mature vines help to create wines with diverse and complex flavour profiles. ‘El Recio’ is made from Tempranillo vines between 90 and 100 years old. So expect heady notes of black fruit, chocolate and vanilla, a full body and a fruity, lingering finish. Enjoy it with juicy lamb shanks.

column1: Bodegas Bardos Ribera del Duero Reserva 2016/18
column2: Bodegas Bardos sits in the toughest and coldest area of Ribera del Duero, at almost 1,000 metres above sea level. The high-altitude brings elegance and freshness to their bold and powerful wines. This Reserva is made from low-yielding Tempranillo and Cabernet Sauvignon vines. Tim Atkin awarded the 2016 vintage with an impressive 96 points. Aged for 16 months in French oak, it has excellent structure, with balanced tannins and refreshing acidity. Discover rich notes of dark fruit, chocolate, vanilla and smoky-wood spice. Try it with a lamb casserole.

column1: Bodegas Bardos Ribera del Duero Crianza 2019/20
column2: The high-altitude region of Ribera del Duero is known for its robust and deeply fruity red wines. A short and hot growing season helps produce Tempranillo grapes with intense and complex flavours. Bodegas Bardos works in one of the region's most challenging areas to capture the signature style at its very best. After 14 months in oak, it’s beautifully aromatic and has notes of ripe cherry and blackberry, velvety tannins and a complex, spicy finish. The intensity of fruit and fresh acidity make it an excellent pairing for grilled lamb chops.

column1: Cillar D Silos 'Torresilo' 2019/20, Ribera del Duero
column2: As a rule of thumb, older vines have more flavoursome grapes. And this is an intense, complex Temperanillo made partially from 100-year-old vines. Expect concentrated notes of red and black fruit, smooth tannins and a long finish. A first-class Ribera red that's great with roast lamb. Decant this for at least an hour before serving at room temperature.

Since it was founded in 1858, Marqués de Riscal has been one of Spain's most inventive wineries. They were the first to create fresh, fruity Verdejo in the Rueda region. They also make it from older vines (30 years old) than many of the other estates. As older vines nourish the tastiest grapes, you can rest assured that you're in for a real treat. This is smooth, fresh and aromatic with notes of tropical fruits, verbena and fresh-cut grass. Try it with shellfish.

Matsu translates from Japanese as ‘to wait’. It perfectly captures the patient philosophy of Bodega Matsu on their Toro vineyards. This is their remarkable flagship wine. It's sourced from a vineyard that’s now in its second century. The mature vines make for an intensely flavoured, complex wine. Despite the region’s hot and dry climate, it's also incredibly elegant. And unlike neighbouring Ribera Del Duero, Toro wines don't demand the same price tag – making this fine wine even more extraordinary. It has notes of jammy black fruits, smoky, toasty spice and an elegant structure. Perfect for herb-crusted filet mignon.

Much like Ribera Del Duero, the Tempranillo grape is king in the region of Toro. Since the area is not as well-known as its famous neighbour, you can find excellent wines at a lower price. The region’s vineyards strive to survive the fiercely hot, dry climate. In the right hands, hard-working vines create complex and intensely flavoured wines. El Picaro translates as 'the rogue', which perfectly sums up this vibrant, charming wine. With just two months ageing in concrete vats, you can taste its youthful freshness – there’s notes of juicy blackberry and blueberry, liquorice and sweet spice. The perfect choice for cuts of roast beef.

As soon as the team behind Bodega Matsu visited Toro, they knew they had to make wine there. 100-year-old vineyards, perfect soils and a goldilocks climate all pointed to a wine of exceptional quality. La Jefa is made there from these obscure, ancient vines – it's a century in the making, but it's well worth the wait. A wide variety of white grapes were picked by hand and fermented on lees in French oak. So you can expect a seriously lush texture and plenty of flavour. Discover notes of vanilla, ripe stone fruits and cream. Perfect with seafood.

Tempranillo is the Spanish grape variety par excellence and it is grown widely throughout the region of Castilla y Leon, having different local names like Tinta de Toro and Tinta del País. Aromas of red and black berries,with a hint of liquorice. Concentrated flavours of black fruits with a perfect balance between fruit and tannins. Round, soft and persistent. Lamb Tagine, Mediterranean mixed platter or mild cheeses.

Ribera del Duero now rivals Rioja as Spain’s most celebrated region. Its higher altitudes keep it relatively cool. Throw in a drop in nighttime temperature, and this is the perfect recipe for intense red wines. Bodegas Bardos work in some of the Ribera’s toughest spots. And this delicious release is your chance to taste what all the fuss is about. Aged for six months in oak, the Bardos Roble displays charming wild herb notes and a rich palate of dark fruits. Serve with lamb shanks.

column1: Tinto Pesquera Reserva 2017/18, Ribera del Duero
column2: This is a sought-after Ribera del Duero from one of the region's finest estates. It's made from 100% Tempranillo and will age well for the next two decaders. Expect complex aromas of blueberry jam, white pepper, cinnamon and toast. Decant this for at least an hour before serving at room temperature with roast lamb.

We asked some of our most prized winemakers working in Spain to make the best wines possible – no rules, no restrictions, no red tape. The Guv'nor collection was their answer. Made from Tempranillo grapes picked from their favourite vineyards across Spain, it’s a crowd-pleasing wine designed to be shared with good food – and even better company. It’s bold. It’s fruity. It’s a modern Spanish red that goes with everything, especially spicy barbecue meats or anything chargrilled.

Just when you thought all the rules were broken… The Guv’nor VIP is not the best of two worlds, but three. Robbing grapes from some of the biggest names in Spain – Rioja, Ribera del Duero, Toro – this pioneering bandit doesn’t care about tradition, only great taste. It's an upgrade on everything the Guv'nor stands for: better grapes, meticulously applied oak, and an even smoother, fruitier taste. He’s taken Majestic’s number one best-selling wine, and made it even better. The Guv’nor rewrote the rule book on wine, taking away vintages, classifications and restrictions. This wine packs a punch with bold flavours of black cherry, red plum, and blackberry, balanced with a touch of savoury oak and mellow spice. It's like a black forest gateau with a kick. Drink with rich dishes and great company.

When it comes to easy-drinking reds, Felix Solís have mastered the art. They’re the creators of The Guv’nor – our bestselling red. And The Gathering Storm ticks all the same boxes. It hails from La Puebla winery, acquired by Felix Solís after they realised the growing potential of the La Mancha region. After several years of major investment and modernisation, the first wines of La Puebla were launched in 2012 – and they’ve gone from strength to strength ever since. This wine gets its name from the thunderstorms and sandstorms that blow north from the Sahara which affect this arid region. Using a mixture of trellised and bush vines, winegrowers have adapted their methods in these changeable conditions to produce wines that truly deliver fantastic value for money. Soft, juicy and floral, this is a supple style of wine with abundant red berry flavour. Silky tannins result in an exceptionally smooth wine and make it a versatile accompaniment to barbecued meats, pizza or a variety of tapas.

The Guv'nor red is one of our best-ever-selling wines. True to form, this pink sibling also breaks the region and rule-based restrictions to bring you plenty of flavour at great value. It's a blend of Garnacha, Bobal and Tempranillo grapes. Each of these varieties comes from a different area and has a unique identity. Bring them all together, and you get something truly remarkable.

Spain's winemaking rules are notoriously strict and convoluted. Like The its ever-popular red sibling, The Guv'nor Blanco breaks them all. No restrictions on vintage, region or labelling – and the result is a delicious wine that reflects the warm, sunny climate of its homeland. It’s a bold, full-bodied blend of Verdejo and Sauvignon Blanc, with some oak-aged Chardonnay added to dial up the richness.  Discover juicy notes of ripe citrus and tropical fruits that'll sing with the paprika spice of chorizo in Spanish-inspired dishes – try it with seafood paella.
this wine won an IWC award.\",£9.99 per bottle,75CL,Chardonnay,Viura,Natural Cork,9.4,Citrus Fruit

The Guv'nor wines break the winemaking rules to bring you incredible flavour at great value. Like the Guv'nor red, this sparkling wine is produced using fruit from a number of Spain's most popular regions. By carefully blending grapes from a range of areas, a winemaker is unrestricted by regional rules. This means they can take advantage of the best parcels available and create something truly special. This is ripe and fruity, with delicious flavours of peach, strawberry and raspberry.

Freixenet is the biggest name in Cava. But they're not done there. In search of the sparkling wine fit for all occasions, they created this refreshing, balancing, alcohol-free sparkling wine. It has flavours of wild berries, raspberries and tropical fruits and a persistent mousse.

Albariño is usually grown in coastal Spanish regions, but this wine is from a little-known area in Rioja – Valles de Sadacia. You might think that the Rioja region is too hot to nurture a grape that thrives by the sea, but Valles de Sadacia is famed for its dry white wines. And this is a stellar example. Expect apple, citrus and stone-fruit flavours that’ll pair exceptionally well with seafood paella – or, as its label and name suggest, octopus.

column1: Bodegas Care Garnacha Blanca Nativa 2021, Cariñena
column2: Bodegas Care is the brainchild of fourth-generation grape growers with an obsession: they want to create quality modern Spanish wines that are great value for money. Winemaker Óscar Martínez hails from Basque country and has worked with Tempranillo on big-name Rioja brands. Now his focus is producing world-class Garnacha and Carignan (known locally as Cariñena). This is intensely aromatic, with hints of white flowers, citrus and herbs. It’s balanced, exotic and elegant – with freshness and structure. The length is long and rich too.
column9: Blossom, Citrus Fruit, Stone Fruit, Tomato Leaf

column2: Freixenet is the biggest name in Cava. But they're not done there. In search of the sparkling wine fit for all occasions, they created this refreshing, balancing, alcohol-free sparkling wine. It has flavours of tropical fruits and citrus and a persistent mousse.
this wine won an IWC award.\",£17.99 per bottle,75CL,Pedro Ximénez,,Natural Cork,11.3,Toffee

The Gonzalez family have been making exceptional sherry since 1835. And the experience really shines in this cream sherry. It's been aged for an average of eight years, so it's beautifully smooth. Expect notes of raisins, vanilla, caramel and hazelnuts. Try this with your cheese board or a vanilla cheesecake snuggled up in front of the fire.
this wine won an IWC award.\",£16.99 per bottle,75CL,Palomino,,Natural Cork,11.3,Walnut
this wine won an IWC award.\",£13.99 per bottle,75CL,,,Screwcap,13.1,Cream
this wine won the cream sherry trophy at the IWSC awards.\",£26.99 per bottle,37.5CL,Palomino,Pedro Ximénez,Natural Cork,7.7,Sweet Spice

column1: Vilarnau ‘Gaudi’ Organic Rosé Cava Brut Reserva, Penedès
column2: Based just outside Barcelona, Vilarnau are a small, artisan producer dedicated to crafting delicious, high quality Cava. They’re also passionate about protecting the environment – and their sustainable practices have seen them become one of the first wineries to be awarded the Wineries for Climate Protection certification. The grapes for this elegant Cava come from Vilarnau’s own vineyards, which have been certified organic since 2015. Its striking label is inspired by Barcelona’s vibrant mosaic art – and the wine itself will transport you straight to the sunny Spanish streets. You’ll find it fresh and juicy with ripe red-berry flavours and delicate floral aromas. Enjoy it slightly chilled as an apéritif, or with your next al fresco meal.
column9: Bread, Pastry, Raspberry, Red Apple, Strawberry

column2: Founded in 1879, the CVNE winery is famed for producing some of the world’s finest Rioja. Now in their third generation of family ownership, they've added Cava to their Cune brand – and it's been received with praise and excitement. Crafted in the traditional method, this classic example of Spain’s signature sparkling offers excellent value for those looking for quality bubbles – without the price tag of its French counterpart. It’s elegant and creamy with notes of ripe apple and freshly toasted bread. Perfect for celebratory sipping.

column1: Pagos del Rey ‘409’ Ribera del Duero 2020/21
column2: Pagos del Rey was founded in 2002, with the goal of crafting quality wines in Spain’s most prestigious winemaking regions. This rich Ribera del Duero proves that they’ve succeeded. It’s made with both old- and young-vine Tempranillo grapes, which are fermented separately to preserve their individual characters. The young-vine grapes give bright fruit and floral aromas, while the old-vine parcel provides firm tannins and riper fruit notes. The wine is then aged in oak for 409 days, hence its name, followed by several months in bottle. All that attention to detail has paid off – this 2020 vintage was awarded an excellent 92 points from top critic James Suckling. Discover juicy dark-fruit flavours balanced by complex notes of toasted spices, dark chocolate, walnut and tobacco. Its supple tannins and long, savoury finish make it an excellent match for red meats, like roast lamb or peppery beef – or you could choose to cellar it for up to five years.
column9: Black Plum, Blackcurrant, Cedar, Sweet Spice

column2: this wine won an IWC award.\",£9.99 per bottle,50CL,Palomino,,Natural Cork,7.5,Mushroom

column1: Marqués de Cáceres ‘Deusa Nai’ Albariño 2021, Rías Baixas
column2: Fans of Rioja will almost certainly recognise Marqués de Cáceres – a progressive Rioja producer whose wines can be found in over 100 countries. Turning their attention to other iconic regions, they looked to Rías Baixas on Spain’s wild Atlantic Coast – a cool and breezy spot renowned for making Spain's best Albariños. And their decades of experience are evident in this expressive bottle. Expect a crisp, citrusy character with fresh notes of crunchy green apples. Its vibrant minerality, typical of its coastal origin, makes for a perfect seafood pairing.
this wine won an IWC award.\",£26.99 per bottle,37.5CL,Palomino,Pedro Ximénez,Natural Cork,7.5,Fig

Sherry has run through the veins of five generations of the Gonzalez family. The journey began in 1835 with Manuel Maria Gonzalez Angel. His legacy to Sherry? A bodega now packed with barrels in every corner. Tio Pepe was named in honour of Manuel’s uncle, after he discovered barrels of a delicious pale, dry style of sherry that Pepe had made. It's now the world’s best-selling Fino – and for very good reason. It’s deeply refreshing with notes of green apple and toasted almond and a hint of saltiness on the crisp, dry finish. Serve straight from the fridge with classic tapas nibbles, like Manchego cheese, olives and salted almonds.
this wine won an IWSC gold award.\",£26.99 per bottle,37.5CL,Pedro Ximénez,,Natural Cork,5.8,Toffee

This Fino is selected from 2 different Bodegas in the centre of Jerez; the first, provides fresh youthful stock. The second, Almacenista (stock holder)provides the older wine which ensures the wines complexity and secondary characters. Bone dry, the Intense flor character is complemented by almond and fresh apple notes giving a fresh finish. An excellent match for all types of tapas, especially olives, nuts, smoked hams and shellfish, as well as Asian or Indian cuisine. Serve at 6-8oc and consume within 2 weeks of opening.

Selected by Pedro Dauthieu, the wine has an average age of 20 years. The must selected for an Oloroso is always more fragrant but also more robust or as they say in Jerez; basto. It is a highly pure Oloroso, as it has not been blended with anything other than the same style of Oloroso's from near identical butts. Exquisite and fully of complexity, with intense aromas of toasted walnuts and autumn leaves. Warm and expansive on the palate - an excellent match for red meats, casseroles and chicken and Vegetable paellas. Consume within 1 month of opening.

column1: Pedro's Almacenista Selection Palo Cortado Sherry
column2: Very rare style of sherry that falls between the elegance of Amontillado and the richness and complexity of Oloroso. From the cellar of Cayetano del Pino, this is a truly magnificent example of the style.

The Guv'nor, made from Tempranillo grapes by some of our favourite winemakers with no limits, was a huge, full-bodied result - and it just got bigger! Expect punchy notes of blackcurrant and vanilla aplenty in this magnum.

The Gonzalez family’s sherry journey began in 1835 with Manuel Maria Gonzalez Angel. Five generations later, they’re renowned the world over as masters of sherry. Tio Pepe was named in honour of Manuel’s uncle, after he discovered barrels of a delicious pale, dry style of sherry that Pepe had made. This fino is a special limited bottling. It’s drawn from cask in spring, when the presence of yeast in the wine is at its highest. The wine is briefly settled before being bottled without any fining – giving complex flavours and its naturally cloudy appearance. Discover complex aromas and flavours of toasted almonds, soda bread and citrus with a crisp finish. It’s best enjoyed with a selection of savoury tapas, inculding olives and roasted nuts.

Uclés is the Spanish DO you’ve probably never heard of. But we can’t keep a juicy insider-secret to ourselves – so take this wine as our introduction to this up-and-coming denominación de origen. Uclés is in Castile, Spain’s central plateau which is most famous as the setting for Don Quioxte. Grapes are chosen from old vines which only yield a tiny number of grapes. But what they do yield has incredibly concentrated flavours. And because Uclés is at high-altitude, those rich fruit flavours are married with real freshness, so the wine’s velvety rather than jammy. Full-bodied. Juicy. Plush. It’s full of blackcurrant and plum aromas, with a delicious savoury kick of black pepper and woody herbs. Such richness makes it ideal with roasted or char-grilled meats.

Marqués de Riscal made Rioja what it is today. Up until the 1850s the locals had made only light, young wines. Then, in 1858, Riscal introduced the ‘Bordeaux method’, barrel ageing. From that moment on, the practice became integral to Rioja. Today, Riscal Reserva is one of the most famous wines in Spain. Each grape is selected from vines that are at least 50 years old. Mature vines make the tastiest grapes. So the wine is incredibly rich and concentrated. It’s full of summer-berry flavours and notes of liquorice and vanilla spice. Perfect with jamón.

column1: Marqués de Cáceres Rioja Gran Reserva 2014/15
column2: Family-run Marqués de Cáceres was established in the 1970s by Enrique Forner. Situated in the subregion of La Rioja Alta, its reputation for high quality wines now extends across more than 120 countries. Since the 2008 vintage, this Gran Reserva has received only 90+ scores from the world’s best critics. To make it, grapes are hand-harvested from vineyards 650 metres above sea level. The high altitude keeps freshness in the fruit – a very important element of the process, given that a Gran Reserva must be aged for a minimum of five years before release. Discover ripe and elegant notes of plum, strawberry, vanilla, toast and coffee. Pair its plush character with roast lamb and all the trimmings. In 2022, James Suckling awarded the 2015 vintage 94 points.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Red Fruit, Spice

column2: We sent our award-winning buying team all around the world on an exciting new mission: to curate a new collection showcasing the best examples of key regions and core grape varietals – at great prices. From a winery founded in 1985, this wine is made from grapes grown in the clay-rich soils of Rioja Alta and the limestone-clay soils of Rioja Alavesa. The average age of the vines here is over 30 years – and this results in a concentrated and complex wine that over delivers on flavour. Aged in American oak casks for 12-16 months, this is smooth, fruity, and a must-try bottle for any Rioja fan. Expect flavours of red fruits and oaky notes with hints of vanilla. It’s soft and supple, and an ideal, easy-drinking pairing for grilled meats or cheese boards.

Viña Pomal began in Haro, Rioja, in 1904. In its rich history, it's built a long list of admirers, and it was reportedly the choice bodega of Winston Churchill. Today, it continues with its innovative ways, and this Reserva wows the critics seemingly with every vintage. It has flavours of red fruits and toasty oak. Try it with red meat and grilled vegetables.

If you’ve drunk Rioja, you’re almost guaranteed to have come across Marqués de Cáceres. Since the 1970s they’ve been producing quality wines in the Spanish region. Their expertise certainly shows in this Crianza. The grapes, primarily Tempranillo, are grown on plots in Rioja Alta and Rioja Alavesa, then aged for 12 months in oak to lend aromas of toasted wood and spices. It’s full of candied red fruit flavours and very smooth to drink, thanks to elegant tannins. A wine for a gourmet burger, comforting stew or chorizo-based dishes.
this wine won an IWC award for the 2019 vintage.\",£9.99 per bottle,75CL,Grenache,Tempranillo

In 1973 a group of friends in a Haro dining club wanted to make Rioja that was designed to go with the food they loved. They more than succeeded. 50 years later, Beronia’s wines are still renowned for their food-friendliness. This Reserva spends 20 months ageing in oak, creating a deliciously velvety red. It's rich, ripe and full of red-fruit flavour. The oak-ageing shows itself in elegant toasty notes of coconut and vanilla, rounded off with spice and smooth tannins. An ideal bottle for your Sunday roast.
this wine won an IWC award for the 2018 vintage.\",£14.99 per bottle,75CL,Tempranillo,,Natural Cork,10.9,Vanilla

column1: La Rioja Alta 'Viña Ardanza' Rioja Reserva 2015/16
column2: La Rioja Alta is the gold standard for traditional Rioja bodegas. This stellar vintage of their Viña Ardanza is a return to their classic Garnacha/Tempranillo blend. It's made from 30-year-old vines and aged for three years in oak. This brings you an indulgently rich Reserva with plenty of ripe fruit flavour and silk-smooth tannins. It has notes of red fruits, vanilla, liquorice and cinnamon. Perfect with roast chicken and lamb.

Some of the best things only come with time. That's certainly the case for Beronia. This was aged for 28 months in oak barrels and three years in the bottle before it was released. It's been mellowing and maturing for four years since – and this gives you that classic Gran Reserva character. This wine has been transformed over time into something incredibly rich, smooth and velvety. Best decanted for an hour before serving with a roast dinner. This wine has won a gold medal at the 2023 IWSC for the 2015 vintage.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Cedar, Cocoa, Dried Fruit, Red Fruit, Spice

column2: Viña Alarde is an award-winning bodega, producing reliably delicious Rioja. They’re owned by Marqués de la Concordia – one of a collection of premium wineries. And they bring all their expertise to this classic Reserva. This great value wine is made in a fresh style – it’s fruity and rich, as well as spicy from its Rioja-standard ageing in oak barrels. It’s fruity, rich and brambly with a touch of vanilla spice. Its velvety tannins make it a delicious partner for roast lamb.

Beronia was founded in 1973 by a group of friends who visited La Rioja on holiday. They had a love of its food and wine and even had their own gastronomic society. They were driven by this shared passion and decided to create their own wine to pair with local cuisines – and Bodegas Beronia was born. It's bright and vibrant with red fruits, blackberry and vanilla notes. It's aged for 12 months in oak. This is a short period of time by Rioja standards. As a result, it's all about maximum fruit flavour. Try it with Iberian cold cuts.

The bar for good quality Rioja used to begin with Crianza. But in recent years, winemakers have begun paying more attention to the potential of the youthful ‘Joven’ style. With little, or zero oak ageing, these wines are amazingly fresh, with pure, juicy fruit flavour. This comes from one of the largest wineries in the subregion of Rioja Alta. They’ve been awarded Best Spanish Winery no less than 9 times at International wine competitions – a sure sign of excellent quality wine. This 100% Tempranillo is smooth, bright and fresh with notes of violet, cherry and strawberry. Try it with creamy mushroom linguine.

Gran Reserva is the crème de la crème of Rioja. It’s the level of Rioja which experiences the most oak ageing – giving it the most structure and ageing potential. This is aged for three years in oak casks which gives it delicious coconut spice – it then spends a further three years in bottle. Such care and attention usually adds up to a big price tag, but this is a real steal. The lengthy ageing process makes for a flavoursome wine with both fresh and dried-fruit flavours. Think cherry, strawberry and cranberry. Smooth. Full. Lusciously spicy. It’s delicious with a roast dinner.

column1: Bodegas Olarra 'Dehesa de Lantana' Rioja Gran Reserva 2015
column2: Gran Reserva Rioja must spend at least two years in barrel, followed by a further three years in bottle. This extended ageing creates a more savoury, spicy style from contact with wood and slow oxidation. The Dehesa de Lantana is a delicious example of this evocative style with dark cherry flavours and aged notes of leather and tobacco.

column1: Marqués de Murrieta Rioja Gran Reserva 2014/15
column2: Marqués de Murrieta began in 1852 and is the oldest estate to stand in Rioja Alta. The winemaker here today is Maria Vargas, who was Tim Atkin MW's Winemaker of the Year in 2017. This is a full-bodied and generous Gran Reserva Rioja, with flavours of red and dark fruits, spicy oak and vanilla. Decant for at least half an hour before serving at 16-18 degrees with a roast dinner.

Bodegas Roda is one of Rioja's forward-thinking producers. They began just over 30 years ago and aim to show the modern face of the region. As a result, they're quickly gaining plenty of fans. They age this Reserva in French, as opposed to American, oak. This gives a much more subtle oak influence to the wine. Think well-integrated chocolate and tobacco that join hints of black fruit and plum. Try it with a roast dinner.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Red Cherry, Red Fruit

column2: Muga are as classic as Rioja gets. They even make their own oak barrels to get the ageing process spot on. Their reds may make the headlines, but this Rioja Blanco is a real hidden gem. It's rested on its lees and aged in oak for three months. As a result, there's a deliciously subtle texture to its flavours of citrus, apple and white flowers. Try it with grilled fish.

column1: La Rioja Alta 'Finca Martelo' Rioja Reserva 2016/19
column2: La Rioja Alta are one of the biggest names in Rioja. They craft this Reserva only in perfect vintages, so you can expect excellence in every bottle. The Tempranillo vines on the Torre de Oña estate are over 60 years old – resulting in a wine with incredible concentration and complexity. Add two years of ageing in oak barrels, and you've got all the hedonistic qualities of delicious Rioja. Expect rich flavours of wild strawberry, cherry and redcurrant accompanied by notes of pastry, biscuit, vanilla, liquorice and pepper. Its silky tannins and long, elegant finish make it a fantastic partner for braised and roasted meats.

Muga is one of the most respected Bodegas in Rioja. But it doesn't stop at reds. Predominantly Garnacha, its Rioja Rosado is more intense and fruity than you'd find in France, but it retains a delicious dry character. Pair its red apple and tropical notes with your next alfresco meal.
this wine won an IWC award for the 2018 vintage.\",£11.99 per bottle,75CL,Tempranillo,,Natural Cork,10.5,Vanilla
this wine won an IWC award for the 2020 vintage.\",£12.99 per bottle,75CL,Viura,,Screwcap,9.8,Banana
this wine won an IWC award for the 2017 vintage.\",£24.99 per bottle,75CL,Tempranillo,Mazuelo
column7: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Dried Herbs, Red Fruit

column2: White Rioja fell out of fashion, but it’s made a comeback and with wines like this it’s easy to see why. It’s evidence that sometimes, patience wins the game. And we’ve had to wait an awful long time for this. It’s made using grapes from vines up to an extraordinary eighty years old. Vines of this age yield really tiny portions of grapes so all the flavours are intensified – you can taste it in this deeply aromatic wine. It’s nutty, rich and full with a really moreish creamy texture. It’s a heady wine, packed with the flavours of ripe yellow fruits – but it’s also nice and crisp. Think pear, quince and honey, with a citrusy backbone. This is wonderful with salty, tapas-style food like salted almonds or Serrano ham.
this wine won an IWC award for the 2017 vintage.\",£14.99 per bottle,75CL,Tempranillo,Mazuelo

When the Limousin family began Bodegas Olarra in 1970, they soon set a new standard of winemaking in Rioja. And they’ve built more than a reputation for quality. Their winery is an iconic landmark on Rioja’s landscape, with a patchwork of pointed roofs covering Olarra’s vast underground cellar. The distinguished architecture has earned it the nickname ‘The Great Cathedral of Rioja’. Today, the estate is managed by the family’s third generation, with one of Spain's best winemakers, Javier Martínez de Salinas, having been on board since 1998. Working with growers across Rioja Alta, Baja and Alavesa, only the best grapes are selected to make this Reserva. It spends 18 months in oak casks before it's left to rest in bottle to develop complexity. Discover vibrant notes of red berries, liquorice and hints of smokiness. Savoury flavours make it a great choice for roast game dishes. In 2022, both Wine Enthusiast and Decanter awarded the 2018 vintage more than 90 points.

When you’re after a classic bottle, you can’t do better than this – a bold Rioja from a family who’ve been making it for 80 years. The fourth-generation Pérez Cuevas family farm high-altitude plots at up to 800 metres in the  Sierra de Yerga mountains. They are working to make all their vineyards 100% organic and are continuously promoting biodiversity. Olive trees and other native flora are dotted among their picturesque vineyards. Expect plenty of bold strawberry and cherry flavours, with hints of vanilla and spice – the perfect accompaniment to roast lamb.
column9: Black Cherry, Black Plum, Coconut, Sweet Spice

column2: Located in the heart of Rioja Alta, Marqués de Cáceres started off as a family business. Today, their wines can be found in 120 countries. Their secret? They specialise in producing exceptional Tempranillo, the main grape that goes into Rioja. Their decades of experience can be tasting in their Reserva, which is aged for 20 months in oak, and then refined for a minimum of two years in the bottle. Because of this, you can expect exquisite flavours of cherry, vanilla and toast. Enjoy over the next six years with roast lamb or game birds.

In 1879, two brothers, Eusebio and Raimundo Real de Asúa, founded CVNE. It's still run by one of their direct descendants and based in the heart of Haro – the capital of Rioja. But far from being constrained by tradition, CVNE is known as an innovator. Take this Crianza. It’s a really modern style, made from a single plot of their oldest vines. They have an average age of 30 years old, so yields are low – and fewer grapes mean more concentrated flavour. Bright. Supple. Fresh. It's full of juicy red-fruit flavours, making it ideal for tapas dishes.

column1: Muga 'Conde de Haro' Brut Cava 2019, Rioja
column2: Muga is considered winemaking royalty in Rioja. They’re the only cellar in Spain with a master cooper and three in-house barrel-makers. But their expertise goes beyond their world-famous reds. Their delicious Cava has all the character and complexity to rival some of the finest Champagnes. Made in the traditional method, it undergoes a slow and lengthy secondary fermentation over 3-4 months. And this patience results in the perfect balance between flavour and finely textured bubbles. A blend of native Viura and Chardonnay, it’s a complex and textured reminder of why Cava is enjoying such a forceful resurgence in popularity. It’s fresh and elegant, with complex and creamy notes of lemon, grapefruit and biscuit, plus hints of fresh pastry and dried fruits.

Muga is arguably the most traditional bodega in Rioja. It’s based next to the railway station – the heart of old Haro, and there’s not a stainless-steel tank in sight. They even have their own cooper to give their barrels the perfect amount of toasting. Unsurprisingly, this Reserva is a real classic. It’s a masterclass in ageing, spending 36 months in oak before further resting in the bottle. The long maturation gives it incredible structure and complexity. Full. Smooth. Supple. Its flavours are richly complex. Think blackberry, vanilla, coffee and a hint of spice. This will easily last for a decade – but it's delicious now. Enjoy it best with rack of lamb.

The CVNE winery is one of the most iconic in Rioja. Founded in 1879, it's now in its third generation of family ownership. This classic Gran Reserva is made under their ever-popular Cune brand. The team use grapes from old vines – 45 years old, on average – which ensures the flavours are superbly concentrated. It’s aged for two years in oak, then spends at least three years in CVNE’s cellars to really dial up the complexity. Expect flavours of black fruits, spice and leather, with subtle vanilla notes and firm tannins. The wine will continue to develop in the bottle, but if you can’t wait to try it, its richness and structure are a perfect match for stews and casseroles.
column9: Black Fruit, Red Fruit, Spice, Vanilla

column2: A remarkable rosado made from 100% Garnacha from high altitude bush vines that are as old as 90-years-old. Lightly oaked, but still fresh, the Flor de Muga is a grown up rosé with excellent texture and elegant flavours of peach and cantaloupe melon and a stony minerality.

This is an intense, silky Rioja Reserva from an excellent modern-day bodega. It has notes of ripe black fruit and mocha, and a long finish. This will go excellently with rib-eye steak and black pepper sauce.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Red Fruit, Spice

column1: La Rioja Alta ‘904’ Rioja Gran Reserva 2011/15
column2: Back in 1890, five Riojan and Basque families came together to form a collective winery. They grew further in the early 1900s, creating the landmark '904' Gran Reserva to celebrate the event. La Rioja Alta is now one of the most-respected names in Rioja. And they’re still making that wine today. It's crafted mostly from Tempranillo and aged for four years in barrel and even longer in the bottle. This patience, and the resulting high quality, makes it suitable for long ageing. It has complex aromas of blackberry jam, raspberries, cedar and cigar box, with liquorice and clove flavours. Thanks to its maturity, it’s perfect for roasted meats.
column9: Black Fruit, Cigar Box, Red Fruit, Spice, Vanilla

column2: The land that Lopez de Haro calls home has been used to make wine for 2,000 years. It's no wonder, as their vineyards are perfectly positioned to get the best out of the hot Riojan sun. This Rioja Rosado is a blend of Garnacha and Viura with a silky, moreish flavour. It's packed full of hints of red fruit, banana, and flowers. We can't think of a better wine to serve with lamb.

column1: Lopez de Heredia 'Viña Tondonia' Rioja Reserva 2010/11
column2: This is a blend of estate-grown grapes aged for six years in oak. It has aromas of vanilla and dried fruit, flavours of rich red fruit, fine tannins and a long finish. Decant for an hour and serve at room temperature with garlic-rubbed lamb or cellar for a decade.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Red Fruit, Spice

column1: Marqués de Riscal Rioja Gran Reserva 2016/17
column2: Marqués de Riscal were the first bodega to apply Bordeaux methods in Rioja. And this changed Spanish winemaking forever. Today, they make this Rioja from 80-year-old vines and age it for 32 months in oak and three years in the bottle. The result is intense and indulgent, with flavours of black fruit and toasted oak, smooth tannins and a long finish. Serve this at room temperature with a roast dinner or cellar until 2030.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Red Fruit, Spice

column1: Marqués de Riscal Rioja Reserva 2017/18 Half Bottle
column2: Marqués de Riscal made Rioja what it is today. Up until the 1850s the locals had made only light, young wines. Then, in 1858, Riscal introduced the ‘Bordeaux method’, barrel ageing. From that moment on, the practice became integral to Rioja. Today, Riscal Reserva is one of the most famous wines in Spain. Each grape is selected from vines that are at least 50 years old. Mature vines make the tastiest grapes. So the wine is incredibly rich and concentrated. It’s full of summer-berry flavours and notes of liquorice and vanilla spice. Perfect with Jamón.

column1: Muga Rioja Prado Enea Gran Reserva 2015
column2: Muga's legendary Prado Enea scored 99 points when James Suckling listed it as number #3 of his 'Top Wines in the World'. It also bagged 96 Parker Points and 97 from Tim Atkin MW. You'll struggle to find a more decorated Rioja, and you'll taste the brilliance of three years of ageing in a silky palate that's full of blackcurrant, forest-floor, tobacco and vanilla notes.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Cocoa, Prune, Red Fruit

column2: Muga is arguably the most traditional bodega in Rioja. The estate even has its own cooperage – a reflection of the care and precision that goes into their winemaking. ‘Special Selection’ is only made in the very best years. It's a powerful, complex wine. You’ll find intense aromas of ripe red and black berries, coffee, and subtle hints of mint and smoky oak. It’s silky smooth in texture with well-structured tannins and spice. The fresh acidity and smokiness will complement a rich game dish like bacon-wrapped roast partridge.
column9: Vanilla, Black Fruit, Red Fruit, Spice

column2: Crianza is Rioja at its fruit-forward best. The Boyante is aged for a year in American oak to smooth tannins and unleash the plentiful red fruit notes. Violets, bramble fruits and perfumed jasmine aromas entwine with hints of pepper and sweet spice.

column1: Rioja Reserva Marques de Riscal 2016/18 Magnum
column2: In 1858, Don Guillermo Hurtado de Amézaga, the Marqués de Riscal brought groundbreaking winemaking techniques from Bordeaux and transformed the face of Rioja. The Reserva is one of their iconic wines, widely regarded as one of the top examples of traditional Rioja. A classic Rioja Reserva. Full bodied and muscular, yet smoothly polished and embellished with complex aromas of vanilla and toasted oak, combined with summer fruit flavours. This wine goes well with ham, cheeses, and spicy casseroles. Will age for a further 5+ years.

column1: Rioja Reserva Viña Ardanza 2015/16 Magnum, La Rioja Alta
column2: One of the very best of Rioja's produced from fruit exclusively grown in the bodega's 360 hectare vineyard holdings in the Rioja Alta region, and named after one of the Region's founding families. Remaining under family ownership, this is of the most sought-after bodegas. Complex and perfumed primary and secondary aromas of earth, spice and red fruits with a long, elegantly structured medium weight body of spicy tannins and layers of flavour. Enjoy over the next decade as the richness and power will soften to spice and earth, augmenting game casserole or wild duck.
column9: Black Fruit, Red Fruit, Spice, Vanilla

column2: This is Muga's top wine and one of the finest examples of the modern Reserva. From the best sites and some of the oldest vines in this historic estate, it spends 3 months in large wood vats then 18 months in new French oak. The result is a polished and complex wine with layers of black fruit, graphite and dried flowers. With an unctuous texture akin to great Pomerol it has fantastic balance and real ageing potential. Drink it over the next 10-12 years.

column1: La Garnatxa Fosca 2020/21 Proyecto Garnachas de España, Priorat
column2: Proyecto Garnachas de España is a project led by Raul Acha to protect Spain's old Garnacha vines. To craft this red, he's used vines over 60 years old, from slate-rich soils, in the acclaimed region of Priorat. The combination of old vines and slate soils have created a red with complex notes of dark cherry, cedar, herb and 'crushed rock' minerality.
column9: Strawberry, Dried Herbs, Leather, Red Plum

column1: Vallformosa Fest Brut Organic Cava, Penedes
column2: A big name in Cava, Vallformosa has been making Spain’s signature fizz since the 1930s, and they've racked up plenty of awards along the way. And yet the team – headed by winemaker Xavi Pons – doesn’t rest on its laurels. Since the early 2000s they’ve been focused on both environmental and social sustainability, using fewer natural resources and supporting a network of 500 long-term local growers. The attention to detail hasn’t shifted, and all wines are aged for longer than the legal requirement, bringing more complex flavour to your glass. This is delicate, balanced fizz with bright notes of apple, pear and citrus.
column9: Apricot, Bread, Cream, Green Apple, Melon, Pear

column1: Vallformosa Fest Brut Rosé Cava, Penedes
column2: Vallformosa is one of the most respected names in Cava. They’ve been making Spain’s famed bubbly since the 1930s, and today work with more than 500 small growers. They lay claim to the high vineyards in Penedes, where grape ripening is slower and flavours and aromas are enhanced. Taste the complexity for yourself in this delicate rosé with fresh notes of strawberry, raspberry and cherry.
column9: Cream, Pear, Raspberry, Red Apple, Red Cherry, Strawberry

column1: Agricola Fuster 'Dardell' Organic Red 2020/21, Terra Alta
column2: The mountainous region of Terra Alta certainly lives up to its name. Here, the peaks reach heights of up to 950 metres – and all that altitude makes for some seriously elegant wines. The Agricola Fuster estate lies right in the heart of the region. It’s been in winemaker Pepe Fuster’s family for three generations, and thanks to his philosophy of sustainability and self-sufficiency, it’s been certified organic for over 15 years. Pepe crafts this smooth red with a blend of Garnacha and Syrah grapes. It’s juicy and fresh with notes of raspberry, spice and a hint of smoke that’ll pair perfectly with Spanish-inspired ham dishes.

column1: Agricola Fuster 'Dardell' Organic White 2021/22, Terra Alta
column2: Terra Alta means 'high land' in Catalan, so it's no surprise that the mountainous region is famed for its elegant high-altitude wines. Winemaker Pepe Fuster was the first to plant Viognier in the region, and he's blended his mature vines with Garnacha Blanca to make this organic white. Expect a delightful roundness from the Garnacha and rich apricot and peach flavours from the Viognier.

Alvaro Palacios is one of Spain's finest winemakers. This is a chance to taste his expertise at a reasonable price. It's a blend of old vine Carignan and Garnacha grapes picked on steep Priorat slopes. Expect a ripe and concentrated wine, with velvety notes of black fruit, firm tannins and hints of spice. Decant for an hour before serving at room temperature with slow-cooked pork.

column1: Vinos del Viento Garnacha Blanca 2021, Aragón
column2: Winemaker Michael Cooper hails from California but has lived in Spain for more than two decades and made wine in Aragón since 2009. He’s all about producing one-of-a-kind, terroir-driven wines in small quantities from premium vineyards sites. Your bottle of Garnacha Blanca is one of a batch of just 6,000 – so make sure you savour every last drop. Hand-harvested from a single high-altitude plot, the Garnacha Blanca grapes that go into making this wine come from dry-farmed old vines. When combined with a dash of Chardonnay aged on lees, the result is a refreshing bottling rich in citrus, rocket and melon aromas.

Northen Spain offers some of the most classic expressions of Garnacha (or Grenache), with this wine being a notable example, made from grapes harvested from ancient 'wild' bush vines in the mountainous Moncayo end of the Ebro Valley. Powerful aromas of wild berries and tobacco leaf are tempered by a sense of freshness and floral edges. The middleweight palate has ripe red fruit and a Burgundian minerality, with subtle French oak. Drink with barbecued red meats or spicy chorizo.

Viña Albali was created by the renowned international wine group, Félix Solís Avantis. This is a great-value Cabernet-Tempranillo blend. What it lacks in alcohol, it more than makes up for in flavour. It's fresh and juicy with notes of red cherry and violets. Great with pizza.

Viña Albali was created by the renowned international wine group, Félix Solís Avantis. This is a great-value Sauvignon Blanc. What it lacks in alcohol, it more than makes up for in flavour. It's juicy and fresh with notes of exotic fruit and citrus. Enjoy with tapas.

Viña Albali was created by the renowned international wine group, Félix Solís Avantis. This is a great-value Garnacha Rosé. What it lacks in alcohol, it more than makes up for in flavour. It's juicy and fresh with bright red-fruit and mandarin notes. Enjoy with salads.

column1: Marques de Calado Rosé 2020 Vino de la Tierra Castilla
column2: Central Spain is one of the most diverse and prolific wine producing regions in Europe, and is the source of many great value wines such as this fruit-driven rosé. A short maceration gives a light, delicate and easy-drinking style. An intense pink wine with plenty of juicy berry fruit. Strawberry and raspberry flavours are complemented by a creamy texture and crisp, refreshing acidity. A perfect summertime apéritif!

A field blend is a rich tapestry of grape varieties plucked from one spot. So we expected something very special from Más Querido. But even we were blown away by the praise of top wine critics last year. This follow-up vintage is a punchy cocktail of orange peel, lime and passionfruit.

Winemaker Series celebrates some of our favourite people behind the bottles. Katia Álvarez is head winemaker at Martín Códax, which is arguably the biggest name in Rías Baixas wine. She was named one of Spain's top ten women winemakers by The Drinks Business. And if you like Albariño, you've almost certainly tried her work before. This time, she's gone slightly off piste, creating this wine in Monterrei from Godello grapes. It's very refreshing, with flavours of passionfruit and pineapple and a sea-spray minerality that's great with seafood.

Owned entirely by local growers, Cooperativa del Barco de Valdeorras have been in operation for half a century and are skilled at growing native Spanish variety Mencía. With 300 members and, in Francisco Cao, the same technical director for more than 30 years, they’ve shown themselves to be consistently excellent. Who better to lead your introduction to Galician red wine? This bottling is vibrant, smooth and bursting with notes of red fruits. Lively acidity and beautiful balance means it’ll go a treat with a variety of dishes, inlucding barbecued meats, cheese and lightly spicy foods. Try it slightly chilled – you won’t regret it.
column9: Red Cherry, Red Fruit, Sweet Spice

column2: Martín Códax was named after a Galician troubadour whose medieval poems are love songs to the sea. If the soil and the sun are the main characters in the story of Albariño, then the sea is the supporting act. The wild Atlantic coastline forces growers up to high altitudes. Here, the sea tempers the climate, so it’s more cool and damp than neighbouring regions. This Albariño is Rías Baixas in a bottle. The grapes are grown in terrifyingly steep amphitheatres overlooking the waves – you can taste the salt in the air in your glass.  Peachy. Citrusy. Fresh. It’s the perfect seaside wine, so it’s no surprise that it’s made for seafood – for octopus, for piles of clams and hard-won goose barnacles, a Galician speciality.
this wine won an IWC award for the 2021 vintage.\",£13.99 per bottle,75CL,Albarino,,Screwcap,9.8,Peach

Think Albariño, think citrussy, zingy, intensely refreshing whites. This wine has all that in spades – but it also has a little something extra. It’s from Val do Salnés, is the oldest sub-region of Rías Baxias right on the coast. It’s known as the birthplace of the Albariño grape – and it’s the coolest and wettest part of the region. It means the Albariños from here are extra crisp and green-fruity. They age this on the lees which gives the wine even more complexity and a lovely viscous texture which works incredibly with all those zingy, citrussy flavours. It’s a really special, unusual Albariño which is perfect if you love both crisp whites and richer styles of wine. But there’s a catch. Only 1,100 cases of this wine were made – so be quick. It’ll be ideal alongside a seafood platter.
column9: Wet Stones, Apricot, Bread Dough, Lemon, Peach

column2: Martín Códax are Albariño experts, based in Rías Baixas DO, the homeland of Albariño. It’s led by ninth-generation winemaker Luciano Amoedo alongside ultra-talented Katia Álvarez, who's been celebrated as one of Spain’s Top Women Winemakers by The Drinks Business. Using their vast experience, the grapes for this wine are picked from vines over 100 metres above sea level. This slows the grapes' maturation, meaning that once they reach ripeness, they’re filled with intense flavour. Expect mineral-lined flavours of plush stone fruit. Its gentle saline undertone will go beautifully with grilled white fish.
column9: Wet Stones, Apricot, Bread Dough, Lemon, Peach

column2: If you like Rioja, you've almost certainly tried CVNE's excellent work before. This is one of their newest projects. And they're so proud of it, they named it after the founder's mother. It's Mencía made in the Valdeorras zone of Galicia. This grape is rapidly rising in popularity in Spain. For good reason. It's widely celebrated for its wonderful aromatics. Think Pinot Noir with the florality turned right up. Expect rich notes of black fruits, fresh acidity and soft tannins. Try it with chorizo.

Before Martín Códax, Rías Baixas DO, the homeland of Albariño, didn't exist. The 50 founding families who saw its potential fought for the region to become a Denominación de Origen. It's down to them that Albariño is so popular today. This wine was voted our customers' favourite wine of 2019. So you can expect something great. Expect a bright, peachy white wine with charming notes of white flowers. It’s intensely refreshing with a citrusy zing. Perfect for seafood.

Family-owned Chozas Carrascal was founded in 1990 as a passion project of Julián López and María José Peidro, both keen to revitalise the area. After 10 years of research they went fully organic and now, under the stewardship of their children, Maria and Julian López-Peidro, the winery is a stalwart of sustainable viticulture. As well as grapes, they encourage the growth of holm oaks, thyme and lavender to aid biodiversity. Everything you’re looking for in a delicious Spanish red. Ripe red-fruit aromas waft from your glass, rippled with toasty and balsamic notes. And when you sip? Medium-bodied, silky-smooth and completely moreish.
column9: Black Cherry, Cinnamon, Red Fruit, Strawberry

column2: The vineyards at Bodegas Volver are a winemakers dream. Located 2,000 feet above sea level, some of them are as old as 90 years. This means low yields but an amazing concentration of flavour in the few grapes. Never tried a wine from Alicante? Take one sip of this wine, and you'll wonder why you didn't sooner. The powerful fruit flavours of bramble fruit and dark cherry are lifted by an elegant floral finish. Enjoy this with grilled lamb.
